caption:
This photograph captures a scene at a gasoline station, likely from the 1970s or 1980s, based on the design of the cars and attire of the people. The setting is a Standard gas station, as indicated by the prominent signage, including the distinctive Chevron logo with a red and blue Chevron shape.

Foreground:
- A black luxury sedan is situated at the left side of the photograph, prominently placed in front of a sign that reads, “Is Your Number Even Today,” which suggests a system of fuel rationing or purchase limitations based on license plate numbers.
- A silver sports car is partially visible next to the black sedan.

Background:
- In the middle ground, there are several people around the cars. One man, dressed in winter clothing with a padded jacket, is conversing with the driver of a yellow Porsche.
- Multiple other vehicles of various models are visible in the background, including a white car with a taxi sign on it.

Setting:
- The overall setting shows a fuel station with multiple fuel dispensers, housed under a large roof supported by pillars.
- Several large billboards and signage are visible, including advertisements and labels associated with car maintenance and fuel products.

Environment:
- The sky appears overcast, suggesting it might be a cold or damp day, which is supported by the attire of the people.

The photograph illustrates a daily life scene, potentially in an urban setting due to the built environment and density of vehicles and signs, focused on people interacting and going about their tasks at a gas station during a time of controlled fuel distribution.
title: Oregon's odd-even plan reduced the lines at gas stations during the fuel crisis in the fall and winter of 1973-74.  This station was servicing cars with even-numbered last digits on their license plates on an even-numbered calendar day
